questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Which two statements are correct about the collections before v3. DELETE is executed?

choices.E: The values of v3 (32) (2) and v1 (2) are identical.
choices.A: The values of v3(31) (2) and v3 (33) (2) are identical.
choices.C: The value of v3 (31) (1) and v3 (33) (3) are identical,

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
CE is correct
E. is the only only answer. The statement says what is the value of the collection before v3.DELETE
CE is the correct answer

A,B,E
Did it at server

comments.content: A is wrong see the last statement in the question.

discussion.content: I think correct answers are: AE

choices.C: DBMS_LOB.COMPARE is overloaded and can compare CLOBs with BLOBs.
choices.B: DBMS_LOB.COMPARE returns the size difference of the compared LOBs.
choices.D: If the destination LOB is a temporary LOB, the row must be locked before calling DBMS_LOB.CONVERTTOBLOB.
choices.A: DBMS_LOB.COMPARE can compare parts of two LOBs.
choices.E: Before calling DBMS_LOB.CONVERTTOBLOB, both the source and destination LOB instances must exist.

discussion.content: AE, not DE. D is false because it says temporary instead of persistent.

comments.content:
COMPARE: Compares two entire LOBs or parts of two LOBs. You can only compare LOBs of the same datatype. 

CONVERTTOBLOB: Reads character data from a source CLOB or NCLOB instance, converts the character data to the specified character, writes the converted data to a destination BLOB instance in binary format, and returns the new offsets. You can use this interface with any combination of persistent or temporary LOB instances as the source or destination. Both the source and destination LOB instances must exist. If the destination LOB is a persistent LOB, the row must be locked. To lock the row, select the LOB using the FOR UPDATE clause of the SELECT statement.

discussion.content: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/arpls/DBMS_LOB.html#GUID-FDD375E4-77B4-482E-9984-0E1CABDA3FC7

Selected Answer: AE
According to documentation eg here https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ARPLS/d_lob.htm
AE is the correct answer

https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/appdev.111/b28419/d_lob.htm#BABEAJAD
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/appdev.111/b28419/d_lob.htm#i1020355

A -> ref " This function compares two entire LOBs or parts of two LOBs."
E -> ref " Both the source and destination LOB instances must exist. "
 ref link -> https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/appdev.111/b28419/d_lob.htm#BABDDFDH
A,E. D would have been true only if the lob was persistent.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about the DBMS_ LOB package?

discussion.content: DF, not EF.

Selected Answer: DF
Initialize correctly and you need to extend VARRAYs
DF is correct.
DF is correct
D,F is the corrct answer

choices.F: Add names_varray.EXTEND after the FOR …LOOP statement.
choices.E: Replace the NAMES_VARRAY declaration with names_varray 1_name_type := null;
choices.C: Add name_rec name_cur%ROWTYPE; at the end of the DECLARE section.
choices.B: Replace the L_NAME_TYPE declaration with TYPE 1_name_type IS VARRAY (25) OF SYS_REFCURSOR;
choices.A: Replace the FOR loop with FOR name_rec IN names_varray.FIRST .. names_varray.LAST LOOP.
choices.D: Replace the NAMES_VARRAY declaration with names_varray 1_name_type := 1_name_type ();

questions.question_text:
The STUDENTS table with column LAST_NAME of data type VARCHAR2 exists in your database schema.
Examine this PL/SQL block:
//IMG//

Which two actions must you perform for this PL/SQL block to execute successfully?
Which two blocks of code execute successfully?

choices.D: DECLARE TYPE tab_type IS TABLE OF NUMBER; my_tab tab_type; BEGIN my_tab := tab_type (); my_tab (1) := 55; END;
choices.A: DECLARE TYPE tab_type IS TABLE OF NUMBER; my_tab tab_type; BEGIN my_tab (1) :=1; END;
choices.E: DECLARE TYPE tab_type IS TABLE OF NUMBER my_tab tab_type := tab_type (2, NULL, 50); BEGIN my_tab.EXTEND (3, 2);
choices.C: DECLARE TYPE tab_type IS TABLE OF NUMBER; my_tab tab_type; BEGIN my_tab. EXTEND (2); my_tab (1) := 55; END;
choices.B: DECLARE TYPE tab_type IS TABLE OF NUMBER; my_tab tab_type := tab_type(2); BEGIN my_tab(1) :=55; END;

discussion.content: B and E are the right answer
B and E

Selected Answer: BE
BE is correct, only ones using correct initialization
BE is correct

The ANs E missing ";" "end;". Anyhow i check it and seems that the correct answers are BC.
The answer E could be fine if it was : 

"DECLARE TYPE tab_type IS TABLE OF NUMBER; my_tab tab_type := tab_type (2, NULL, 50); BEGIN my_tab.EXTEND (3, 2); END;"

and not 

DECLARE TYPE tab_type IS TABLE OF NUMBER my_tab tab_type := tab_type (2, NULL, 50); BEGIN my_tab.EXTEND (3, 2);

comments.content:
sorry, C cannot be the correct answer cause: ORA-06533;
Correct ans BE

discussion.content: B and E

Selected Answer: AD
AD are the only viable options here
A and D are correct answer.

PRAGMA AUTHID is put on the question just to trick you (AUTHID works with SQL engine to verifies privilleges of an SQL user)
Result Cache is used to trick you (if yu use sysdate the result of the function will never be cached).
The answer is A and D (change the return type of the function and data type of local variable so the result of the function will be presented in the defaulte date format of the specific user)
A and D
I think B and D
A and D
A and D
CE. result_cache_mode = force only makes sense for queries, not functions.

comments.content: C and D don't make sense together. C assigns a varchar2 to l_date and D changes the type of of l_date to DATE. Won't compile like that.

discussion.content: c and d are the right answer

choices.D: Change the data type of 1_date to DATE.
choices.A: Change the RETURN type to DATE.
choices.F: Set the RESULT_CACHE_MODE parameter to FORCE.
choices.E: Set NLS_DATE_FORMAT to ‘DD-MM-YY’ at the instance level.
choices.C: Use the TO_CHAR function around SYSDATE, that is, 1_date := TO_CHAR (SYSDATE).

questions.question_text:
Examine this code:
//IMG//

Users of this function may set different date formats in their sessions.
Which two modifications must be made to allow the use of your sessions date format when outputting the cached result of this function?
